<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="spar0045" view="all">A pair of new enantiomers <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> consisting of Lewis acid and Lewis basic were successfully synthesized, which act as bifunctional catalysts displaying high catalytic activity and selectivity in the synergic catalysis Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A pair of new enantiomers NH2-Co-PYIs consisting of Lewis acid and Lewis basic were successfully synthesized, which act as bifunctional catalysts displaying high catalytic activity and selectivity in the synergic catalysis Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Two enantiomers NH2-Co-PYIs were synthesized by introducing the Lewis acid and base catalytic groups into one single MOF.   ⋅  NH2-Co-PYIs have excellent properties of unambiguous crystalline structure, economic chemical reagents and highly stability.   ⋅ The orderly distributed and spatial matching of multiple catalytic active sites enhanced their reactivity through a synergistic cooperation.   ⋅  NH2-Co-PYIs display high catalytic activity and selectivity in Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation under mild conditions.

elements.clean_text:
Two enantiomers NH2-Co-PYIs were synthesized by introducing the Lewis acid and base catalytic groups into one single MOF.

 NH2-Co-PYIs have excellent properties of unambiguous crystalline structure, economic chemical reagents and highly stability.

The orderly distributed and spatial matching of multiple catalytic active sites enhanced their reactivity through a synergistic cooperation.

 NH2-Co-PYIs display high catalytic activity and selectivity in Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation under mild conditions.

Abstract

Recently, great interest is focused on developing synergic catalysis that the reactants are bound and oriented at two different centers. In this context, by simultaneously introducing Lewis acid and Lewis basic into a polyoxometalate based metal-organic framework, a pair of enantiomer NH2-Co-PYIs were achieved and characterized by IR, PXRD, CD, TGA. NH2-Co-PYIs displayed high catalytic activity and selectivity in synergic catalysis Aldol/Knoevenagel condensation as bifunctional catalysts. Multiple catalytic active sites were orderly distributed and spatial matching, which would be a powerful approach to increase the stability and the corresponding functions and to enhance their reactivity through a synergistic cooperation between different catalysis sites.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0025" view="all">The <ce:italic>α,β</ce:italic>-unsaturated carbonyl compounds are a kind of important pharmaceutical intermediates, such as the top-selling drugs pregabalin and pioglitazone []. Aldol and Knoevenagel reaction are powerful and practical tools for synthesis of <ce:italic>α,β</ce:italic>-unsaturated carbonyl compounds []. During the past two decades, the mono-catalysis strategy has been successfully delivered with several Lewis acid, organometallic compounds, ionic liquids and amines as catalysts to promote Aldol and Knoevenagel condensations under homogeneous conditions []. Especially, secondary amines are an effective promoter, in which the formation of the iminium intermediate derived from the amine and a carbonyl compound plays a key role in promoting condensation []. However, the aforementioned systems have restrictions including inevitable by-products, catalyst recovery, environmental pollution and harsh reaction conditions [,]. Therefore, great attention has been dedicated to the development of heterogeneous base catalysts rendering green and sustainable process [,].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds are a kind of important pharmaceutical intermediates, such as the top-selling drugs pregabalin and pioglitazone []. Aldol and Knoevenagel reaction are powerful and practical tools for synthesis of α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds []. During the past two decades, the mono-catalysis strategy has been successfully delivered with several Lewis acid, organometallic compounds, ionic liquids and amines as catalysts to promote Aldol and Knoevenagel condensations under homogeneous conditions []. Especially, secondary amines are an effective promoter, in which the formation of the iminium intermediate derived from the amine and a carbonyl compound plays a key role in promoting condensation []. However, the aforementioned systems have restrictions including inevitable by-products, catalyst recovery, environmental pollution and harsh reaction conditions [,]. Therefore, great attention has been dedicated to the development of heterogeneous base catalysts rendering green and sustainable process [,].

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0030" view="all">Compared with the previous single-site catalysis, a powerful approach is to develop the multifunctional catalytic system, which incorporates multiple catalytic centers such as metal complexes and organic molecules together to promote Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation reaction in a cooperative catalysis []. Recently, we focus on developing two-center catalysis promoted by complexes with Lewis acidity, Lewis or Brönsted basicity [,]. However, the biggest challenge for the successful implementation of two-center catalysis is not only to combine appropriate catalytic active sites into one structure, but also to realize the compatibility between reaction intermediates and the consistency of the reaction rates [,].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compared with the previous single-site catalysis, a powerful approach is to develop the multifunctional catalytic system, which incorporates multiple catalytic centers such as metal complexes and organic molecules together to promote Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation reaction in a cooperative catalysis []. Recently, we focus on developing two-center catalysis promoted by complexes with Lewis acidity, Lewis or Brönsted basicity [,]. However, the biggest challenge for the successful implementation of two-center catalysis is not only to combine appropriate catalytic active sites into one structure, but also to realize the compatibility between reaction intermediates and the consistency of the reaction rates [,].

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0035" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention and undergone explosive development over recent years for their intriguing architectures and the potential applications in heterogeneous catalysis []. One of the most superiority of MOFs is that delicate functional groups either enantiopure organic ligands or their metal complexes can be blended directly by self-assembly, endowing them with multiple functionalities and new features distinctively different from the components []. In particular, the introduction of polyoxometalates (POM) into the multi-level hierarchical framework at the molecular scale would increase the complexity, stability and corresponding functionality, providing a promising way to combine synergistically the interacting organic and inorganic catalytic activity components [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention and undergone explosive development over recent years for their intriguing architectures and the potential applications in heterogeneous catalysis []. One of the most superiority of MOFs is that delicate functional groups either enantiopure organic ligands or their metal complexes can be blended directly by self-assembly, endowing them with multiple functionalities and new features distinctively different from the components []. In particular, the introduction of polyoxometalates (POM) into the multi-level hierarchical framework at the molecular scale would increase the complexity, stability and corresponding functionality, providing a promising way to combine synergistically the interacting organic and inorganic catalytic activity components [].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0040" view="all">In this context, by incorporating multiple modified catalytic sites such as asymmetric organocatalytic group pyrrolidine-2-yl-imidazole (PYI), NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- functionalized bridging link (NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY), Keggin-type [CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> anions, cobalt(II) ions into a single structure, a pair of enantiomers POMOF catalysts [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPYI)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)][CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI2)</ce:bold> were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0005"></ce:float-anchor>). Multiple catalytic active sites were orderly distributed and spatial matching, which would be a powerful approach to increase the stability and the corresponding functions and to enhance their reactivity through a synergistic cooperation between different catalysis sites.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this context, by incorporating multiple modified catalytic sites such as asymmetric organocatalytic group pyrrolidine-2-yl-imidazole (PYI), NH2- functionalized bridging link (NH2-BPY), Keggin-type [CoW12O40]6- anions, cobalt(II) ions into a single structure, a pair of enantiomers POMOF catalysts [Co2(NH2-BPY)2(HPYI)2(H2O)(CH3CN)][CoW12O40] (NH2-Co-PYI1 and NH2-Co-PYI2) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions ( ). Multiple catalytic active sites were orderly distributed and spatial matching, which would be a powerful approach to increase the stability and the corresponding functions and to enhance their reactivity through a synergistic cooperation between different catalysis sites.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0045" view="all">All reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification. L- and D-N-tert-butoxycarbonyl-2-(imidazole)-1-pyrrolidine (<ce:italic>L</ce:italic>- or <ce:italic>D</ce:italic> -BCIP), 3-amino-4,4-bipyridine (NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY) [] and [(n-C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[W<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>] [] were prepared according to the literature methods and characterized by IR spectroscopy. The elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. W and Co analyses were performed on a Jarrel-AshJ-A1100 spectrometer. The infrared spectra (IR) were recorded from a sample powder palletized with KBr on a Nicolet170 SXFT-IR spectrometer over a range of 4000-400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a Rigaku Model D/Max-2400 X-ray diffractometer with a sealed copper tube (λ = 1.54178 Å). TG analysis was recorded on a Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e instrument with a heating rate of 10 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> heated from 25 to 800 °C under nitrogen. <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian INOVA-400 MHz type (<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H, 400 MHz) spectrometer. Circular dichroism spectra were measured on JASCO J-810 with solid KBr tabletting.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All reagents were commercially purchased and used without further purification. L- and D-N-tert-butoxycarbonyl-2-(imidazole)-1-pyrrolidine (L- or D -BCIP), 3-amino-4,4-bipyridine (NH2-BPY) [] and [(n-C4H9)4N]4[W10O32] [] were prepared according to the literature methods and characterized by IR spectroscopy. The elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. W and Co analyses were performed on a Jarrel-AshJ-A1100 spectrometer. The infrared spectra (IR) were recorded from a sample powder palletized with KBr on a Nicolet170 SXFT-IR spectrometer over a range of 4000-400cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a Rigaku Model D/Max-2400 X-ray diffractometer with a sealed copper tube (λ=1.54178Å). TG analysis was recorded on a Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e instrument with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 heated from 25 to 800°C under nitrogen. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian INOVA-400MHz type (1H, 400MHz) spectrometer. Circular dichroism spectra were measured on JASCO J-810 with solid KBr tabletting.

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0050" view="all">The <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> was prepared by the self-assembly approach under hydrothermal conditions. A mixture of [(n-C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N]<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>[W<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>] (66.4 mg, 0.02 mmol), Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (60.0 mg, 0.20 mmol), NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY (10.3 mg, 0.06 mmol) and L-BCIP (7.5 mg, 0.03 mmol) were mixed in 4 mL of water and 2 mL of methanol solution. The resultant mixture was stirred for 12 h, then pH value was adjusted to 4.3 with acetic acid (HAc) and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and maintained at 130 °C for 3 days. After cooling the autoclave to room temperature, black rod-like single crystals were separated, washed with water and air-dried. (Yield: calculated (calcd) 72% based on [(n-C4H9)4N]4[W10O32]). Elemental analyses and inductively coupled plasma calcd (%) for C38H55N13O42.5W12Co3: C 12.12, H 1.45, N 4.84, Co 4.71, W 58.74;. Found: C 12.14, H 1.47, N 4.84, Co 4.70, W 58.72 for NH2-Co-PYI1. elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0045">Crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0060" view="all">The good single crystals of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> with dimensions of 0.35 × 0.24 × 0.16 mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> and 0.37 × 0.24 × 0.16 mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> were stuck on a glass fiber, and intensity data were collected at 296 K on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71073 Å), respectively. Routine Lorentz polarization and Multi-scan absorption correction were applied to intensity data. Their structures were determined and the heavy atoms were found by direct methods using the SHELXTL-97 program package []. The remaining atoms were found from successive full-matrix least-squares refinements on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and Fourier syntheses [,]. Positions of the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon and nitrogen atoms were geometrically placed. Not all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms within the ligand backbones were fixed geometrically at their positions and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The summary of crystal data and structure refinements for compound <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl0005"></ce:float-anchor>. CCDC 1850836 and 1850837 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref id="intr0005" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data</ce:inter-ref>_request/cif.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The good single crystals of NH2-Co-PYIs with dimensions of 0.35×0.24×0.16 mm3 and 0.37×0.24×0.16 mm3 were stuck on a glass fiber, and intensity data were collected at 296K on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å), respectively. Routine Lorentz polarization and Multi-scan absorption correction were applied to intensity data. Their structures were determined and the heavy atoms were found by direct methods using the SHELXTL-97 program package []. The remaining atoms were found from successive full-matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 and Fourier syntheses [,]. Positions of the hydrogen atoms attached to carbon and nitrogen atoms were geometrically placed. Not all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms within the ligand backbones were fixed geometrically at their positions and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The summary of crystal data and structure refinements for compound NH2-Co-PYIs are summarized in  . CCDC 1850836 and 1850837 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0050">Catalytic reaction</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0055">Knoevenagel condensation reactions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0065" view="all">The <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> (0.01 mmol) was stirred in 1 mL of CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> solution, benzaldehyde (1 mmol) and ethyl acetoacetate (1 mmol) were added and the mixture was stirred for seven days at 45 °C temperature. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered and extracted. The organic extracts were dried by Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and evaporated to dryness. The yields were directly determined by <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR analysis of the reaction solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic reaction

Knoevenagel condensation reactions

The NH2-Co-PYI1 (0.01mmol) was stirred in 1mL of CH2Cl2 solution, benzaldehyde (1mmol) and ethyl acetoacetate (1mmol) were added and the mixture was stirred for seven days at 45°C temperature. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered and extracted. The organic extracts were dried by Na2SO4 and evaporated to dryness. The yields were directly determined by 1H NMR analysis of the reaction solution.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0060">Asymmetric aldol reactions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0070" view="all">The <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> (0.01 mmol) was stirred in 1 mL of DMSO solution for 15 min, and aldehyde (0.5 mmol), cyclohexanone (5 mmol) and acetic acid (0.20 mL) were added, then the mixture was stirred for seven days at room temperature. The mixture was treated with 1 mL of saturated aqueous ammonium chloride solution and extracted with ethyl acetate. The conversion and distereoselectivity were directly determined by <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR analysis of the reaction solution. The organic layer was dried with anhydrous MgSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, filtered, and concentrated to give after column chromatography (hexanes/ethyl acetate (4:1)) pure aldol adducts. The <ce:italic>ee</ce:italic> was determined by chiral HPLC analysis (Chiralpak AD, Daicel Chemical Industries, Ltd.) When the solvent was replaced by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH: H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (V/V = 1:1), the mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (2mL*3), and the organic layer was dried with anhydrous MgSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, filtered, and concentrated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Asymmetric aldol reactions

The NH2-Co-PYIs (0.01mmol) was stirred in 1mL of DMSO solution for 15min, and aldehyde (0.5mmol), cyclohexanone (5mmol) and acetic acid (0.20mL) were added, then the mixture was stirred for seven days at room temperature. The mixture was treated with 1mL of saturated aqueous ammonium chloride solution and extracted with ethyl acetate. The conversion and distereoselectivity were directly determined by 1H NMR analysis of the reaction solution. The organic layer was dried with anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated to give after column chromatography (hexanes/ethyl acetate (4:1)) pure aldol adducts. The ee was determined by chiral HPLC analysis (Chiralpak AD, Daicel Chemical Industries, Ltd.) When the solvent was replaced by CH3OH: H2O (V/V=1:1), the mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (2mL*3), and the organic layer was dried with anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0065">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0070">Structural description</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0075" view="all">Single-crystal structural analysis revealed that <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co − PYI1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI2</ce:bold> shared the same cell dimensions crystallized in the chiral space group <ce:italic>P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>.</ce:italic>
<ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI2</ce:bold> was prepared similarly to <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>, except that <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>‒BCIP replaced <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>‒BCIP. Elemental analysis along with powder X-ray analysis (PXRD) of the compound indicated the pure phase of its bulky sample (Fig. S1). Circular dichroism (CD) spectrum of the bulk sample of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> presented positive cotton effects at 245 nm (θ = 31.6 mdeg) and negative cotton effects at 300 nm (θ = -75.7 mdeg). The CD spectrum of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI2</ce:bold> exhibited the cotton effects that were opposite to <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>, as expected for a pair of enantiomers with a mirror-imager relationship (Fig. S2) [,]. The molecular asymmetric structural unit of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> contains a Keggin anion CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> unit (the precursor W<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">4-</ce:sup> anion is labile under hydrothermal conditions and favours to rearrangement into the more stable Keggin-type CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> anion) and a cation [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPYI)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)]<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> (Fig. S3). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0020"></ce:float-anchor>a, both Co(2) ion and Co(3) ions adopt distorted octahedral geometries (Fig. S4). The crystallographically independent Co(2) ion is defined by one oxygen atom from coordinated water, two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup>, two nitrogen atoms from NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY and one nitrogen atom from PYI. The removability of the coordinated water molecules indicates the potential of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> to act as an active Lewis acid catalyst (a). The coordination environment of Co(3) ion is defined by two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup>, two nitrogen atoms from NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY, one nitrogen atom from PYI, and one nitrogen atom from CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN. Each of these CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> anion acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect with four Co ions through the terminal oxygen atoms forming a 2D square grid sheet (b). Then the 2D square grid sheet are further bridged by the NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY ligands coordinating with two different Co ions to form a three-dimensional <ce:bold>
<ce:italic>nbo</ce:italic>
</ce:bold> topology (6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)framework with one-dimensional chiral channels along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (c, S5). According to the calculated from PLATON analysis, the accessible empty space of the framework is approximately 236.8 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (6.6%), which suggested that the MOF-based material <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> has the possibility for absorbing substrates within its pores. TGA revealed that the frameworks are stable up to ∼360 °C (Fig. S6). <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> exhibits high chemical and thermal stability, which satisfies most of the conditions of the ideal platform for heterogeneous catalysis. The coexistence of the Lewis acid catalyst Co(II), chiral organocatalyst PYI and Lewis base catalyst NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY in one framework would provide a synergistical catalytic way to accelerate the aldol and Knoevenagel condensation [,].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structural description

Single-crystal structural analysis revealed that NH2-Co-PYI1 and NH2-Co-PYI2 shared the same cell dimensions crystallized in the chiral space group P21. NH2-Co-PYI2 was prepared similarly to NH2-Co-PYI1, except that D-BCIP replaced L-BCIP. Elemental analysis along with powder X-ray analysis (PXRD) of the compound indicated the pure phase of its bulky sample (Fig. S1). Circular dichroism (CD) spectrum of the bulk sample of NH2-Co-PYI1 presented positive cotton effects at 245nm (θ=31.6 mdeg) and negative cotton effects at 300nm (θ = -75.7 mdeg). The CD spectrum of NH2-Co-PYI2 exhibited the cotton effects that were opposite to NH2-Co-PYI1, as expected for a pair of enantiomers with a mirror-imager relationship (Fig. S2) [,]. The molecular asymmetric structural unit of NH2-Co-PYI1 contains a Keggin anion CoW12O40 6- unit (the precursor W10O32 4- anion is labile under hydrothermal conditions and favours to rearrangement into the more stable Keggin-type CoW12O40 6- anion) and a cation [Co2(NH2-BPY)2(HPYI)2(H2O)(CH3CN)]6+ (Fig. S3). As shown in  a, both Co(2) ion and Co(3) ions adopt distorted octahedral geometries (Fig. S4). The crystallographically independent Co(2) ion is defined by one oxygen atom from coordinated water, two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW12O40 6-, two nitrogen atoms from NH2-BPY and one nitrogen atom from PYI. The removability of the coordinated water molecules indicates the potential of NH2-Co-PYI1 to act as an active Lewis acid catalyst (a). The coordination environment of Co(3) ion is defined by two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW12O40 6-, two nitrogen atoms from NH2-BPY, one nitrogen atom from PYI, and one nitrogen atom from CH3CN. Each of these CoW12O40 6- anion acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect with four Co ions through the terminal oxygen atoms forming a 2D square grid sheet (b). Then the 2D square grid sheet are further bridged by the NH2-BPY ligands coordinating with two different Co ions to form a three-dimensional  nbo  topology (6482)framework with one-dimensional chiral channels along the b axis (c, S5). According to the calculated from PLATON analysis, the accessible empty space of the framework is approximately 236.8Å3 (6.6%), which suggested that the MOF-based material NH2-Co-PYI1 has the possibility for absorbing substrates within its pores. TGA revealed that the frameworks are stable up to ~360°C (Fig. S6). NH2-Co-PYI1 exhibits high chemical and thermal stability, which satisfies most of the conditions of the ideal platform for heterogeneous catalysis. The coexistence of the Lewis acid catalyst Co(II), chiral organocatalyst PYI and Lewis base catalyst NH2-BPY in one framework would provide a synergistical catalytic way to accelerate the aldol and Knoevenagel condensation [,].

<ce:section-title id="sect0075">Catalysis Knoevenagel/Aldol condensation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0080" view="all">Knoevenagel condensation has been considered as one of the most important reactions for generating <ce:italic>α,β</ce:italic>-unsaturated carbonyl compounds by additive reaction of aromatic aldehydes with activated methylene compounds [,]. In this work, <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> are explored in the new synergic catalytic system for Lewis base NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Lewis acid Co(II) coexisting in one framework, which can effectively active the substrates in a synergistic cooperation for the preparation of substituted alkene derivatives. We initially investigated reaction conditions using benzaldehyde and ethyl acetoacetate as a model substrate with <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> in a heterogeneous mixture at 45 °C for seven days, which furnished the yield almost up to 100% (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl0010"></ce:float-anchor>, Entry 1) (see SI for additional information). The excellent reaction efficiency revealed the successful execution of our design.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalysis Knoevenagel/Aldol condensation

Knoevenagel condensation has been considered as one of the most important reactions for generating α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds by additive reaction of aromatic aldehydes with activated methylene compounds [,]. In this work, NH2-Co-PYIs are explored in the new synergic catalytic system for Lewis base NH2 and Lewis acid Co(II) coexisting in one framework, which can effectively active the substrates in a synergistic cooperation for the preparation of substituted alkene derivatives. We initially investigated reaction conditions using benzaldehyde and ethyl acetoacetate as a model substrate with NH2-Co-PYI1 in a heterogeneous mixture at 45°C for seven days, which furnished the yield almost up to 100% ( , Entry 1) (see SI for additional information). The excellent reaction efficiency revealed the successful execution of our design.

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0085" view="all">A series of control experiments were carried out for benzaldehyde under the similar condition. It is found that the reaction become inert in the absence of catalyst <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1.</ce:bold> The control experiments employing the NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY and Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as catalyst under the similar condition gave a conversion of 28% and 25%, respectively. To further investigate the synergistic interactions between the amine and the inorganic Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, a reference MOF <ce:bold>BPY-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> was assembled using the same starting components with same stoichiometry <ce:bold>(</ce:bold>see Fig.S7<ce:bold>)</ce:bold>. <ce:bold>BPY-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> displayed the same structure with <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>, except that the bridging ligand 4,4-bipyridine <ce:bold>(BPY)</ce:bold> replaced <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY</ce:bold>. Since Ni―<ce:bold>BPY</ce:bold> possessed the similar channels constructed by the same POM anions and chiral directors, it is thus an excellent reference for investigating the catalytic activity of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> on the same Knoevenagel condensation reaction. <ce:bold>BPY-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> gave a 65% conversion under identical reaction conditions, which was far lower than that with the <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> as catalyst. The higher conversion in the present of the <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> system is maybe due to the synergistic cooperation of Co(II) ions and NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> groups in activating methylene and carbonyl compounds. In 2016, Elhamifar’s group also reported a primary amine-functionalized ionic liquid-based periodic mesoporous organosilica and investigated how the amine group activated methylene group of ethyl cyanoacetate [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A series of control experiments were carried out for benzaldehyde under the similar condition. It is found that the reaction become inert in the absence of catalyst NH2-Co-PYI1. The control experiments employing the NH2-BPY and Co(NO3)2 as catalyst under the similar condition gave a conversion of 28% and 25%, respectively. To further investigate the synergistic interactions between the amine and the inorganic Co2+, a reference MOF BPY-Co-PYI1 was assembled using the same starting components with same stoichiometry (see Fig.S7). BPY-Co-PYI1 displayed the same structure with NH2-Co-PYI1, except that the bridging ligand 4,4-bipyridine (BPY) replaced NH2-BPY. Since Ni-BPY possessed the similar channels constructed by the same POM anions and chiral directors, it is thus an excellent reference for investigating the catalytic activity of NH2-Co-PYI1 on the same Knoevenagel condensation reaction. BPY-Co-PYI1 gave a 65% conversion under identical reaction conditions, which was far lower than that with the NH2-Co-PYI1 as catalyst. The higher conversion in the present of the NH2-Co-PYI1 system is maybe due to the synergistic cooperation of Co(II) ions and NH2 groups in activating methylene and carbonyl compounds. In 2016, Elhamifar's group also reported a primary amine-functionalized ionic liquid-based periodic mesoporous organosilica and investigated how the amine group activated methylene group of ethyl cyanoacetate [].

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0090" view="all">To further verify whether the catalysis take place on the surface or in the channel of MOFs, a bulky aldehyde, 3′,5′-di-tert-butyl-[1,1′-biphenyl]- 4-carbaldehyde with the larger molecule size than that of the channels was introduced as a comparison, which gave less than 20% of conversion under the same reaction conditions. Moreover, the negligible adsorption by immersing <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> into a solution of bulky aldehyde revealed that the bulky aldehyde is too large to be adsorbed in the channels. It is suggested that the catalysis indeed occur in the channels of the MOF, not on the external surface.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To further verify whether the catalysis take place on the surface or in the channel of MOFs, a bulky aldehyde, 3',5'-di-tert-butyl-[1,1'-biphenyl]- 4-carbaldehyde with the larger molecule size than that of the channels was introduced as a comparison, which gave less than 20% of conversion under the same reaction conditions. Moreover, the negligible adsorption by immersing NH2-Co-PYI1 into a solution of bulky aldehyde revealed that the bulky aldehyde is too large to be adsorbed in the channels. It is suggested that the catalysis indeed occur in the channels of the MOF, not on the external surface.

elements.content: <ce:para id="par0095" view="all">To investigate the influence of substrates on the reaction, the substrates were extended to substituted-benzaldehyde including the electron-withdrawing group and the electron-donating group. The catalytic condensation of halogen-substituted benzaldehydes also exhibited excellent reaction efficiency 88.9% yield for 4-chlorobenzaldehyde (Entry 2). Aldehydes containing a strong electron-donating group, such as either <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> groups, on the benzene ring afforded the corresponding products in moderate yields (Entries 4,5). In all, benzaldehyde derivatives, bearing an electron-drawing group, such as a halogen or nitro group, generally showed slightly higher reactivity than those of benzaldehydes with an electron-donating group (Entry 2,3). When salicylaldehyde (Entry 6) was used as a substrate, the expected Knoevenagel alkene product was not detected. In order to verify the heterogeneity, we removed the <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> by filtration after four days shut down the reaction of benzaldehyde and the filtrate afforded nearly no additional conversion after stirring at 45 ℃ for another 3 days. The observation suggested that the <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> was a true heterogeneous catalyst. The <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> solids could be isolated from the reaction suspension by simple filtration and reused at least three times with moderate loss of activity (from 99% to 95% of yield). The index of XRD patterns of the <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> bulky sample recycling from the catalytic reaction indicated the maintenance of the crystallinity (Fig. S2).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To investigate the influence of substrates on the reaction, the substrates were extended to substituted-benzaldehyde including the electron-withdrawing group and the electron-donating group. The catalytic condensation of halogen-substituted benzaldehydes also exhibited excellent reaction efficiency 88.9% yield for 4-chlorobenzaldehyde (Entry 2). Aldehydes containing a strong electron-donating group, such as either CH3 or OCH3 groups, on the benzene ring afforded the corresponding products in moderate yields (Entries 4,5). In all, benzaldehyde derivatives, bearing an electron-drawing group, such as a halogen or nitro group, generally showed slightly higher reactivity than those of benzaldehydes with an electron-donating group (Entry 2,3). When salicylaldehyde (Entry 6) was used as a substrate, the expected Knoevenagel alkene product was not detected. In order to verify the heterogeneity, we removed the NH2-Co-PYI1 by filtration after four days shut down the reaction of benzaldehyde and the filtrate afforded nearly no additional conversion after stirring at 45 ℃ for another 3 days. The observation suggested that the NH2-Co-PYI1 was a true heterogeneous catalyst. The NH2-Co-PYI1 solids could be isolated from the reaction suspension by simple filtration and reused at least three times with moderate loss of activity (from 99% to 95% of yield). The index of XRD patterns of the NH2-Co-PYI1 bulky sample recycling from the catalytic reaction indicated the maintenance of the crystallinity (Fig. S2).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0100" view="all">One broad C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching vibration at 1688 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> was presented in the IR spectrum of the catalyst NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1 impregnated with benzaldehyde in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> solution (cf. 1701 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> of the free benzaldehyde) (Fig. S8) []. Mechanically speaking, in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, we speculate that the amine group of NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co–PYI1 picks up an acidic proton from the active methylene group of ethyl acetoacetate to produce a corresponding carbanion intermediate. Correspondingly, Co(II) ion as a Lewis-acidic center is available to activation benzaldehyde resulting in the formation of an electrophile carbocation. Then, the carbanion intermediate combines with electrophile carbocations by the nucleophilic attack leading to acarbon-carbon bond, accompany with the formation of the corresponding β-hydroxyl compound by the hydrion polarizes the carbonyl-Co. Finally, the Knoevenagel products are obtained via the dehydration of β-hydroxyl compound and regenerated catalyst [] (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0010"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>

Mechanically speaking, in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, we speculate that the amine group of NH2-Co-PYI1 picks up an acidic proton from the active methylene group of ethyl acetoacetate to produce a corresponding carbanion intermediate. Correspondingly, Co(II) ion as a Lewis-acidic center is available to activation benzaldehyde resulting in the formation of an electrophile carbocation. Then, the carbanion intermediate combines with electrophile carbocations by the nucleophilic attack leading to acarbon-carbon bond, accompany with the formation of the corresponding β-hydroxyl compound by the hydrion polarizes the carbonyl-Co. Finally, the Knoevenagel products are obtained via the dehydration of β-hydroxyl compound and regenerated catalyst [] ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0105" view="all">The aldol reaction is also a key carbon<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>carbon bond-formingreaction in nature and repertoire of the synthetic chemist []. Enamine catalysis is commonly used in electrophilic <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>-substitution reactions of ketones and aldehydes []. The chiral POMOFs <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> were assessed as catalyst for the asymmetric aldol reactions between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone in DMSO or CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/ H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at room temperature. As listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl0015"></ce:float-anchor> (see SⅡ for additional information), the corresponding catalytic and enantioselective activities varied significantly with different aldehydes. The reactions catalyzed by <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> in DMSO media produced aldol products in general yields (60–75%) and with fair to good enantioselectivity for <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-isomers (enantiomeric excess (<ce:italic>ee</ce:italic>), 48–63%). As is expected, a chirality induction effect was observed in the reaction between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone employed in DMSO. Thus, <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> represent the first examples of POM-based heterogeneous asymmetric catalysts for this important reaction, providing a convenient route to aldol reaction. To investigate the influence of the solvent, we employed the reactions in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O media (1:1 ratio). Although the conversion is low, the higher diastereo-selectivity (>98%) and excellent enantioselectivity were obtained, especially, up to 89.15% for the 2-(Hydroxy-(4-nitrophenyl)methyl)-cyclohexan-1-one catalyzed by <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>. It’s worth noting that catalyst <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O media always exhibited excellent specificity for the <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> conformation of the product corresponding to the aldol reactions of the nitrobenzaldehydes rather than the <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> conformation reported in previous literatures []. (Table S1) In <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>, the co-existence of imine as Lewis base and exposed Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions as Lewis acid catalytic sites within one framework will enhanced the activity of the enamine in aldol reaction and avoid the side reactions, such as self-aldolization. A control experiment with free PYI in a homogeneous manner suggested the yield and enantioselectivity are lower than that in the heterogeneous catalyst.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The aldol reaction is also a key carboncarbon bond-formingreaction in nature and repertoire of the synthetic chemist []. Enamine catalysis is commonly used in electrophilic α-substitution reactions of ketones and aldehydes []. The chiral POMOFs NH2-Co-PYIs were assessed as catalyst for the asymmetric aldol reactions between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone in DMSO or CH3OH/ H2O at room temperature. As listed in   (see SⅡ for additional information), the corresponding catalytic and enantioselective activities varied significantly with different aldehydes. The reactions catalyzed by NH2-Co-PYIs in DMSO media produced aldol products in general yields (60-75%) and with fair to good enantioselectivity for anti-isomers (enantiomeric excess (ee), 48-63%). As is expected, a chirality induction effect was observed in the reaction between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone employed in DMSO. Thus, NH2-Co-PYIs represent the first examples of POM-based heterogeneous asymmetric catalysts for this important reaction, providing a convenient route to aldol reaction. To investigate the influence of the solvent, we employed the reactions in CH3OH/H2O media (1:1 ratio). Although the conversion is low, the higher diastereo-selectivity (>98%) and excellent enantioselectivity were obtained, especially, up to 89.15% for the 2-(Hydroxy-(4-nitrophenyl)methyl)-cyclohexan-1-one catalyzed by NH2-Co-PYI1. It's worth noting that catalyst NH2-Co-PYIs in CH3OH/H2O media always exhibited excellent specificity for the syn conformation of the product corresponding to the aldol reactions of the nitrobenzaldehydes rather than the anti conformation reported in previous literatures []. (Table S1) In NH2-Co-PYI1, the co-existence of imine as Lewis base and exposed Co2+ ions as Lewis acid catalytic sites within one framework will enhanced the activity of the enamine in aldol reaction and avoid the side reactions, such as self-aldolization. A control experiment with free PYI in a homogeneous manner suggested the yield and enantioselectivity are lower than that in the heterogeneous catalyst.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="par0110" view="all">In the aldol reaction, Co(II) ion as a Lewis-acidic center is available to activate benzaldehyde resulting in the electrophile carbocations (A). Concurrently, the chiral amine group acts as a chiral inducer and Lewis base centers to activate the carbonyl groups of ketones leading to a nucleophilic EN intermediate (B). Then, the nucleophilic EN intermediates (B) attack the electrophile carbocations furnishing the β- hydroxy lM intermediates (C). Finally, by hydrolysis of enamine (C) and the re-generation of catalyst, the chiral product 4-hydroxy-4-phenylbutan-2-one is generated [] (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0015"></ce:float-anchor>)</ce:para>

Concurrently, the chiral amine group acts as a chiral inducer and Lewis base centers to activate the carbonyl groups of ketones leading to a nucleophilic EN intermediate (B). Then, the nucleophilic EN intermediates (B) attack the electrophile carbocations furnishing the β- hydroxy lM intermediates (C). Finally, by hydrolysis of enamine (C) and the re-generation of catalyst, the chiral product 4-hydroxy-4-phenylbutan-2-one is generated [] ( )

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0080">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0115" view="all">In summary, we have successfully synthesized two new POMOF catalysts <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> under hydrothermal conditions. <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> belong to a particular class of two-center catalyst, which display high catalytic activity and selectivity in synergic catalysis Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation. It will be highly promising for the synthesis of <ce:italic>α,β</ce:italic>-unsaturated carbonyl compounds by synergistical catalytic way because of their advantages in terms of simply structure, inexpensive and readily available chemical reagents and easy-to-produce properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully synthesized two new POMOF catalysts NH2-Co-PYIs under hydrothermal conditions. NH2-Co-PYIs belong to a particular class of two-center catalyst, which display high catalytic activity and selectivity in synergic catalysis Aldol and Knoevenagel condensation. It will be highly promising for the synthesis of α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds by synergistical catalytic way because of their advantages in terms of simply structure, inexpensive and readily available chemical reagents and easy-to-produce properties.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NH2-Co-PYIs 

The NH2-Co-PYI1 was prepared by the self-assembly approach under hydrothermal conditions. A mixture of [(n-C4H9)4N]4[W10O32] (66.4mg, 0.02mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅3H2O (60.0mg, 0.20mmol), NH2-BPY (10.3mg, 0.06mmol) and L-BCIP (7.5mg, 0.03mmol) were mixed in 4mL of water and 2mL of methanol solution. The resultant mixture was stirred for 12h, then pH value was adjusted to 4.3 with acetic acid (HAc) and sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and maintained at 130°C for 3 days. After cooling the autoclave to room temperature, black rod-like single crystals were separated, washed with water and air-dried. (Yield: calculated (calcd) 72% based on [(n-C4H9)4N]4[W10O32]). Elemental analyses and inductively coupled plasma calcd (%) for C38H55N13O42.5W12Co3: C 12.12, H 1.45, N 4.84, Co 4.71, W 58.74;. Found: C 12.14, H 1.47, N 4.84, Co 4.70, W 58.72 for NH2-Co-PYI1. IR (KBr; ν): 3422 (br, s), 1602 (s), 1425 (m), 1099 (w), 931 (s, W=Ot), 873 (s,W-O-W), 765 (s,W-O-W) cm-1.

The preparation of NH2-Co-PYI2 was similar to that of NH2-Co-PYI1, except that D-BCIP (50.0mg, 0.2mmol) replaced L-BCIP. (Yield: ca. 75% based on [(n-C4H9)4N]4[W10O32]). Elemental analyses and inductively coupled plasma calcd (%) for C38H54N13O42W12Co2.5: C 12.25, H 1.47, N 4.90, Co 3.94, W 59.32;. Found: C 12.27, H 1.46, N 4.89, Co 3.96, W 59.33 for NH2-Co-PYI2.

Catalysis Knoevenagel/Aldol condensation

Knoevenagel condensation has been considered as one of the most important reactions for generating α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds by additive reaction of aromatic aldehydes with activated methylene compounds [,]. In this work, NH2-Co-PYIs are explored in the new synergic catalytic system for Lewis base NH2 and Lewis acid Co(II) coexisting in one framework, which can effectively active the substrates in a synergistic cooperation for the preparation of substituted alkene derivatives. We initially investigated reaction conditions using benzaldehyde and ethyl acetoacetate as a model substrate with NH2-Co-PYI1 in a heterogeneous mixture at 45°C for seven days, which furnished the yield almost up to 100% ( , Entry 1) (see SI for additional information). The excellent reaction efficiency revealed the successful execution of our design.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0065">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0070">Structural description</ce:section-title><ce:para id="par0075" view="all">Single-crystal structural analysis revealed that <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co − PYI1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI2</ce:bold> shared the same cell dimensions crystallized in the chiral space group <ce:italic>P2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>.</ce:italic>
<ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI2</ce:bold> was prepared similarly to <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>, except that <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>‒BCIP replaced <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>‒BCIP. Elemental analysis along with powder X-ray analysis (PXRD) of the compound indicated the pure phase of its bulky sample (Fig. S1). Circular dichroism (CD) spectrum of the bulk sample of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> presented positive cotton effects at 245 nm (θ = 31.6 mdeg) and negative cotton effects at 300 nm (θ = -75.7 mdeg). The CD spectrum of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI2</ce:bold> exhibited the cotton effects that were opposite to <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>, as expected for a pair of enantiomers with a mirror-imager relationship (Fig. S2) [,]. The molecular asymmetric structural unit of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> contains a Keggin anion CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> unit (the precursor W<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">4-</ce:sup> anion is labile under hydrothermal conditions and favours to rearrangement into the more stable Keggin-type CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> anion) and a cation [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPYI)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)]<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> (Fig. S3). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig0020"></ce:float-anchor>a, both Co(2) ion and Co(3) ions adopt distorted octahedral geometries (Fig. S4). The crystallographically independent Co(2) ion is defined by one oxygen atom from coordinated water, two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup>, two nitrogen atoms from NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY and one nitrogen atom from PYI. The removability of the coordinated water molecules indicates the potential of <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> to act as an active Lewis acid catalyst (a). The coordination environment of Co(3) ion is defined by two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup>, two nitrogen atoms from NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY, one nitrogen atom from PYI, and one nitrogen atom from CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN. Each of these CoW<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> anion acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect with four Co ions through the terminal oxygen atoms forming a 2D square grid sheet (b). Then the 2D square grid sheet are further bridged by the NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY ligands coordinating with two different Co ions to form a three-dimensional <ce:bold>
<ce:italic>nbo</ce:italic>
</ce:bold> topology (6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)framework with one-dimensional chiral channels along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (c, S5). According to the calculated from PLATON analysis, the accessible empty space of the framework is approximately 236.8 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (6.6%), which suggested that the MOF-based material <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> has the possibility for absorbing substrates within its pores. TGA revealed that the frameworks are stable up to ∼360 °C (Fig. S6). <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold> exhibits high chemical and thermal stability, which satisfies most of the conditions of the ideal platform for heterogeneous catalysis. The coexistence of the Lewis acid catalyst Co(II), chiral organocatalyst PYI and Lewis base catalyst NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-BPY in one framework would provide a synergistical catalytic way to accelerate the aldol and Knoevenagel condensation [,].</ce:para><ce:para id="par0105" view="all">The aldol reaction is also a key carbon<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>carbon bond-formingreaction in nature and repertoire of the synthetic chemist []. Enamine catalysis is commonly used in electrophilic <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>-substitution reactions of ketones and aldehydes []. The chiral POMOFs <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> were assessed as catalyst for the asymmetric aldol reactions between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone in DMSO or CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/ H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at room temperature. As listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl0015"></ce:float-anchor> (see SⅡ for additional information), the corresponding catalytic and enantioselective activities varied significantly with different aldehydes. The reactions catalyzed by <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> in DMSO media produced aldol products in general yields (60–75%) and with fair to good enantioselectivity for <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>-isomers (enantiomeric excess (<ce:italic>ee</ce:italic>), 48–63%). As is expected, a chirality induction effect was observed in the reaction between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone employed in DMSO. Thus, <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> represent the first examples of POM-based heterogeneous asymmetric catalysts for this important reaction, providing a convenient route to aldol reaction. To investigate the influence of the solvent, we employed the reactions in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O media (1:1 ratio). Although the conversion is low, the higher diastereo-selectivity (>98%) and excellent enantioselectivity were obtained, especially, up to 89.15% for the 2-(Hydroxy-(4-nitrophenyl)methyl)-cyclohexan-1-one catalyzed by <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>. It’s worth noting that catalyst <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYIs</ce:bold> in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O media always exhibited excellent specificity for the <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> conformation of the product corresponding to the aldol reactions of the nitrobenzaldehydes rather than the <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> conformation reported in previous literatures []. (Table S1) In <ce:bold>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Co-PYI1</ce:bold>, the co-existence of imine as Lewis base and exposed Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions as Lewis acid catalytic sites within one framework will enhanced the activity of the enamine in aldol reaction and avoid the side reactions, such as self-aldolization. A control experiment with free PYI in a homogeneous manner suggested the yield and enantioselectivity are lower than that in the heterogeneous catalyst.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structural description

Single-crystal structural analysis revealed that NH2-Co-PYI1 and NH2-Co-PYI2 shared the same cell dimensions crystallized in the chiral space group P21. NH2-Co-PYI2 was prepared similarly to NH2-Co-PYI1, except that D-BCIP replaced L-BCIP. Elemental analysis along with powder X-ray analysis (PXRD) of the compound indicated the pure phase of its bulky sample (Fig. S1). Circular dichroism (CD) spectrum of the bulk sample of NH2-Co-PYI1 presented positive cotton effects at 245nm (θ=31.6 mdeg) and negative cotton effects at 300nm (θ = -75.7 mdeg). The CD spectrum of NH2-Co-PYI2 exhibited the cotton effects that were opposite to NH2-Co-PYI1, as expected for a pair of enantiomers with a mirror-imager relationship (Fig. S2) [,]. The molecular asymmetric structural unit of NH2-Co-PYI1 contains a Keggin anion CoW12O40 6- unit (the precursor W10O32 4- anion is labile under hydrothermal conditions and favours to rearrangement into the more stable Keggin-type CoW12O40 6- anion) and a cation [Co2(NH2-BPY)2(HPYI)2(H2O)(CH3CN)]6+ (Fig. S3). As shown in  a, both Co(2) ion and Co(3) ions adopt distorted octahedral geometries (Fig. S4). The crystallographically independent Co(2) ion is defined by one oxygen atom from coordinated water, two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW12O40 6-, two nitrogen atoms from NH2-BPY and one nitrogen atom from PYI. The removability of the coordinated water molecules indicates the potential of NH2-Co-PYI1 to act as an active Lewis acid catalyst (a). The coordination environment of Co(3) ion is defined by two terminal oxygen atoms of CoW12O40 6-, two nitrogen atoms from NH2-BPY, one nitrogen atom from PYI, and one nitrogen atom from CH3CN. Each of these CoW12O40 6- anion acts as a tetradentate ligand to connect with four Co ions through the terminal oxygen atoms forming a 2D square grid sheet (b). Then the 2D square grid sheet are further bridged by the NH2-BPY ligands coordinating with two different Co ions to form a three-dimensional  nbo  topology (6482)framework with one-dimensional chiral channels along the b axis (c, S5). According to the calculated from PLATON analysis, the accessible empty space of the framework is approximately 236.8Å3 (6.6%), which suggested that the MOF-based material NH2-Co-PYI1 has the possibility for absorbing substrates within its pores. TGA revealed that the frameworks are stable up to ~360°C (Fig. S6). NH2-Co-PYI1 exhibits high chemical and thermal stability, which satisfies most of the conditions of the ideal platform for heterogeneous catalysis. The coexistence of the Lewis acid catalyst Co(II), chiral organocatalyst PYI and Lewis base catalyst NH2-BPY in one framework would provide a synergistical catalytic way to accelerate the aldol and Knoevenagel condensation [,].

The aldol reaction is also a key carboncarbon bond-formingreaction in nature and repertoire of the synthetic chemist []. Enamine catalysis is commonly used in electrophilic α-substitution reactions of ketones and aldehydes []. The chiral POMOFs NH2-Co-PYIs were assessed as catalyst for the asymmetric aldol reactions between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone in DMSO or CH3OH/ H2O at room temperature. As listed in   (see SⅡ for additional information), the corresponding catalytic and enantioselective activities varied significantly with different aldehydes. The reactions catalyzed by NH2-Co-PYIs in DMSO media produced aldol products in general yields (60-75%) and with fair to good enantioselectivity for anti-isomers (enantiomeric excess (ee), 48-63%). As is expected, a chirality induction effect was observed in the reaction between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone employed in DMSO. Thus, NH2-Co-PYIs represent the first examples of POM-based heterogeneous asymmetric catalysts for this important reaction, providing a convenient route to aldol reaction. To investigate the influence of the solvent, we employed the reactions in CH3OH/H2O media (1:1 ratio). Although the conversion is low, the higher diastereo-selectivity (>98%) and excellent enantioselectivity were obtained, especially, up to 89.15% for the 2-(Hydroxy-(4-nitrophenyl)methyl)-cyclohexan-1-one catalyzed by NH2-Co-PYI1. It's worth noting that catalyst NH2-Co-PYIs in CH3OH/H2O media always exhibited excellent specificity for the syn conformation of the product corresponding to the aldol reactions of the nitrobenzaldehydes rather than the anti conformation reported in previous literatures []. (Table S1) In NH2-Co-PYI1, the co-existence of imine as Lewis base and exposed Co2+ ions as Lewis acid catalytic sites within one framework will enhanced the activity of the enamine in aldol reaction and avoid the side reactions, such as self-aldolization. A control experiment with free PYI in a homogeneous manner suggested the yield and enantioselectivity are lower than that in the heterogeneous catalyst.
